text:
This report details exploration carried out on Yilgangi tenement P31/1420 during the reporting 
 period 6/03/2005 to 05/03/2006. Jackson Gold is the beneficial and/or registered holder of the 
 tenement.  The  Yilgangi  Project  is  located  on  the  Edjudina  Station,  approximately  155  km 
 north northeast of Kalgoorlie (Figure 1). The Project area lies between Lake Rebecca to the 
 south and Lake Raeside to the north and is located to approximately 10km west of the former 
 Porphyry Gold Mine. The tenement is located on the Edjudina 1:250 000 Sheet (H 51-06) and 
 is situated in the Yerilla District of the North Coolgardie Mineral Field.  
 A  90%  interest  in  a  package  of  tenements  including  prospecting  licence  P31/1420  was 
 purchased by Jackson Gold Resources from Cazaly Resources Ltd in April 2004 for a cash 
 consideration of $20 000.00 and the issue of Jackson Gold shares to the value of $20 000.00. 
 Cazaly  Resources  Ltd  retained  a  10%  interest  in  the  tenement  and  is  to  be  free-carried  to 
 completion of a decision to mine. Retained encumbrances on the tenement included a $1/tonne 
 mined and milled royalty to International Goldfields Limited. 
 Tenement P31/1420 lies within a sedimentary basin containing coarse clastic rocks which lies 
 immediately  east  of  the  Yilgangi  Fault  and  unconformably  overlies  greenstones  of  the 
 Mulgabbie Terrane. Metamorphosed polymictic conglomerate, wacke, and quartzofeldspathic 
 sandstone  and  siltstone  in  the  sedimentary  basin  are  tightly  folded.  Tenement  P31/1420  is 
 located within an area which is predominatly underlain by a monzogranite and the adjacent 
 sedimentary rocks which have been interpreted as a thick sequence of interlayered felsic flows 
 and polymictic conglomerate.  
 Exploration  activities  included  geological  mapping  and  geochemical  processing  of  surface 
 sample data (Figure 2). 
 2

13.text: Access from Kalgoorlie is via the Yarri road, which is sealed for the first 15 kilometres to

14.text: Kanowna and from there it is a well maintained graded gravel road. The Yarri graded gravel

15.text: road lies just to the north of the property and station tracks and previously cleared grid lies

16.text: provide access within the tenement area.  Much of the area is covered by recent alluvial and

17.text: transported  overburden,  with  salt  pans  and  the  lakes  of  the  Rebecca  system  present  to  the

Details of the Yilgangi Project tenement are presented in Table 1. below. 
 Table 1 : Yilgangi  Project Tenement Details 
 3.1 Regional Geology

 The Yilgangi Project areas lie within the eastern part of the Eastern Goldfields Province of the 
 Yilgarn  Craton  (Swager,  1995).  The  projects  occur  along  the  eastern  boundary  of  the 
 Norseman-  Wiluna  Belt.  The  greenstones  are  divided  into  several  structural-stratigraphic 
 domains separated by major faults or discontinuities. The greenstones are bounded to the west 
 by a granitoid complex that includes strongly foliated to gneissic granitoid, and to the east by a 
 high-grade granite-gneiss-migmatite complex. 
 The  tenement  lies  within  the  Barba  Hills  and  Yarri  Domains,  which  define  an  overall 
 synformal structure, but are separated by a major regional fault, the Yilgangi Fault, which is 
 the  southern  continuation  of  the  Keith-Kilkenny  Fault  (Figure  3).  The  fault  is  overlain  by 
 polymictic conglomerate and other sedimentary rocks.  The Yilgangi Fault forms the western 
 boundary of the Mulgabbie Domain of the Kurnalpi Terrane (Swager, 1997). A sedimentary 
 basin  containing  coarse  clastic  rocks  lies  immediately  east  of  the  Yilgangi  Fault  and 
 unconformably  overlies  greenstones  of  the  Mulgabbie  Terrane.  Metamorphosed  polymictic 
 conglomerate, wacke, and quartzofeldspathic sandstone and siltstone in the sedimentary basin

9.text: Gold mines of the Yilgangi mining centre which are on the Keith- Kilkenny Fault Zone have

10.text: only modest historical production (about 926 t), and occur within a course clastic sequence

11.text: and/or intrusive monzodiorite plugs. At Yilgangi Queen two quartz reefs with carbonate plus

12.text: pyrite haloes were mined from a northern (Heppingstone) and a southern (Melody) shaft, and

13.text: may  be  the  same  reef,  but  faulted  and  displaced.  The  reef  contains  very  shallowly  south-

text:
Gold mines of the Yilgangi mining centre which are on the Keith- Kilkenny Fault Zone have 
 only modest historical production (about 926 t), and occur within a course clastic sequence 
 and/or intrusive monzodiorite plugs. At Yilgangi Queen two quartz reefs with carbonate plus 
 pyrite haloes were mined from a northern (Heppingstone) and a southern (Melody) shaft, and 
 may  be  the  same  reef,  but  faulted  and  displaced.  The  reef  contains  very  shallowly  south-

14.text: plunging ore shoots in westerly dipping shears with or without quartz veins.

16.text: The Yilgangi King deposit is hosted in a massive monzodorite. A total of 636.00t of ore for

17.text: 11.36  kg  Au  (17.9  g/t  Au)  were  produced  between  1924  and  1974.  At  Yilgangi  King  both

18.text: monzodiorite porphyry and metaconglomerates are sheared with carbonate-quartz-sericite and

19.text: pyrite plus arsenopyrite alteration adjacent to quartz veins. Two moderately deep shafts and

20.text: several shallow pits have been sunk over about 100m strike length on a trend of 330 o. A small

21.text: historic open pit at one end of the workings exposes a 330 o – trending quartz vein (10- 20 cm

22.text: wide) that dips about 70o SW. A stacked series of quartz veins and sub-parallel fractures in the

23.text: footwall of this vein dips 15 – 45o NW. Individual quartz veins are up to 1m thick.

25.text: At the Quondong mine gold mineralisation is hosted in a syenite intrusion, with gold being

26.text: associated with quartz veining in brittle reverse faults that trend 330 – 350o and dip 70o to the

29.text: Gold  in  the  Rainbow,  Rainbow  South  (Snowy)  and  Golden  Rainbow  deposits  occurs  in

30.text: irregular quartz veins associated with pyrite and chlorite alteration and silver.

34.text: Much of the project area is covered by recent alluvial and transported material with salt pans

35.text: and  lakes  of  the  Lake  Rebecca  system  present  to  the  south.  Drilling  by  previous  operators

36.text: indicates that the surface cover is thin. The regolith in the area is shown in the Landsat TM

plunging ore shoots in westerly dipping shears with or without quartz veins.  
 The Yilgangi King deposit is hosted in a massive monzodorite. A total of 636.00t of ore for 
 11.36  kg  Au  (17.9  g/t  Au)  were  produced  between  1924  and  1974.  At  Yilgangi  King  both 
 monzodiorite porphyry and metaconglomerates are sheared with carbonate-quartz-sericite and 
 pyrite plus arsenopyrite alteration adjacent to quartz veins. Two moderately deep shafts and 
 several shallow pits have been sunk over about 100m strike length on a trend of 330 o. A small 
 historic open pit at one end of the workings exposes a 330 o – trending quartz vein (10- 20 cm 
 wide) that dips about 70o SW. A stacked series of quartz veins and sub-parallel fractures in the 
 footwall of this vein dips 15 – 45o NW. Individual quartz veins are up to 1m thick. 
 At the Quondong mine gold mineralisation is hosted in a syenite intrusion, with gold being 
 associated with quartz veining in brittle reverse faults that trend 330 – 350o and dip 70o to the 
 Gold  in  the  Rainbow,  Rainbow  South  (Snowy)  and  Golden  Rainbow  deposits  occurs  in 
 irregular quartz veins associated with pyrite and chlorite alteration and silver. 
 Much of the project area is covered by recent alluvial and transported material with salt pans 
 and  lakes  of  the  Lake  Rebecca  system  present  to  the  south.  Drilling  by  previous  operators 
 indicates that the surface cover is thin. The regolith in the area is shown in the Landsat TM

20.text: The first Reward claim in the vicinity of the Yilgangi tenement was pegged in 1903. During

21.text: the  1970’s  exploration  was  carried  out  by  a  number  of  operators,  including  Falconbridge

22.text: Australia  Ltd,  Consolidated  Gold  Fields  Australia  Ltd,  Asarco  Australia  Ltd  and  Otter

23.text: Exploration for copper- nickel and volcanogenic copper-zinc massive sulphide deposits.  In

24.text: the  1980’s  the  exploration  emphasis  changed  to  targeting  gold  deposits.  A  summary  of  the

25.text: gold exploration history of the project area is given below.

34.text: Tectonic  Resources’  Quondong  Gold  Project  covered  the  eastern  margin  of  tenement

35.text: P31/1420. Exploration for gold was conducted over a quartz-feldspar porphyry dyke intruding

36.text: the  greenstone  belt  and  the  surrounding  sediments.  Soil  sampling  failed  to  identify  any

37.text: significant anomalies. RC drilling intersected numerous highly anomalous to semi-economic

49.text: The  Yilgangi  King  gold  project  covered  an  area  which  included  the  majority  of  tenement

50.text: P31/1420. Exploration for gold was conducted in the vicinity of former workings in an area

51.text: comprising of polymictic conglomerate and pebbly greywacke which was intruded by felsic to

52.text: intermediate  porphyry.  Gold  mineralisation  was  found  to  be  associated  with  quartz  veining

53.text: and sericite alteration of the porphyries. RC drilling gave a best intercept of 2m @ 11.2 ppm

54.text: Au near the surface, although the results were generally patchy and low-grade. RAB drilling

text:
The  Yilgangi  King  gold  project  covered  an  area  which  included  the  majority  of  tenement 
 P31/1420. Exploration for gold was conducted in the vicinity of former workings in an area 
 comprising of polymictic conglomerate and pebbly greywacke which was intruded by felsic to 
 intermediate  porphyry.  Gold  mineralisation  was  found  to  be  associated  with  quartz  veining 
 and sericite alteration of the porphyries. RC drilling gave a best intercept of 2m @ 11.2 ppm 
 Au near the surface, although the results were generally patchy and low-grade. RAB drilling

8.text: evident in the aeromagnetic data from their ellipsoidal signature.

northwest  direction,  parallel  to  stratigraphy  (Figure  5.)  The  low  angle  regional  shear  zones

 The  post-regional  folding  granitoids  including  the  Porphyry  Quartz  Monzonite,  are  clearly 
 evident in the aeromagnetic data from their ellipsoidal signature.

17.text: banded  iron  formations  and  porphyry  intrusives  of  the  greenstone  terrane.    Extensive

22.text: Goldfield’s Titus South Prospect is located within the excised portion of tenement P31/1420.

23.text: At  the  Titus  South  Prospect  16  hammer  RAB  holes were drilled for a total of 70m at 40m

24.text: spacings on two lines 200m apart to test anomalous gold in auger soil samples. Cover is thin,

25.text: above  relatively  fresh  conglomerate  and  hematitically  altered  monzogranite  porphyry.  One

26.text: hole  QRB655,  returned  encouraging  results  of  3  consecutive  samples  from  1m  to  4m

27.text: downhole of 0.26 g/t Au, 1.43 g/t Au and 0.30 g/t Au. The hole is between two auger samples

28.text: of 42 ppb Au and 58 ppb Au with the mineralised interval in slightly weathered monzogranite

29.text: porphyry with 6% disseminated pyrite and 3% quartz veining. Holes were drilled towards the

30.text: west  because  there  is  a  slightly  east-dipping  foliation  in  the  outcrop  nearby.    RC  hole

31.text: QRC014, for 100m was drilled at the Titus South Prospect to test the anomalous gold values

32.text: in  RAB  hole  QRB655.  The  hole  intersected  hard,  unaltered  monzonite  porphyry  and

33.text: conglomerate. No values above 0.26 g/t Au were returned and no further work was undertaken

43.text: between 1935 and 1982, Yilgangi which produced 1094.0 t of ore for 18.83 kg Au (17.2 g/t

44.text: Au) between 1903 and 1905 and Yilgangi King which produced 636.00 t of ore for 11.36 kg

45.text: Au (17.9 g/t Au) between 1924 and 1974 (Roberts.F.I. et al., 2000).

text:
The West Porphyry Project consisted of a large package of ground, including the area now 
 covered by P31/1420. It was considered that potential for gold mineralisation existed with the 
 banded  iron  formations  and  porphyry  intrusives  of  the  greenstone  terrane.    Extensive 
 exploration  was  undertaken  which  included  regolith  and  geological  mapping,  rockchip 
 sampling,  geophysical  data  interpretation  and  RAB,  aircore,  RC  and  diamond  drilling  at  a 
 Goldfield’s Titus South Prospect is located within the excised portion of tenement P31/1420. 
 At  the  Titus  South  Prospect  16  hammer  RAB  holes were drilled for a total of 70m at 40m 
 spacings on two lines 200m apart to test anomalous gold in auger soil samples. Cover is thin, 
 above  relatively  fresh  conglomerate  and  hematitically  altered  monzogranite  porphyry.  One 
 hole  QRB655,  returned  encouraging  results  of  3  consecutive  samples  from  1m  to  4m 
 downhole of 0.26 g/t Au, 1.43 g/t Au and 0.30 g/t Au. The hole is between two auger samples 
 of 42 ppb Au and 58 ppb Au with the mineralised interval in slightly weathered monzogranite 
 porphyry with 6% disseminated pyrite and 3% quartz veining. Holes were drilled towards the 
 west  because  there  is  a  slightly  east-dipping  foliation  in  the  outcrop  nearby.    RC  hole 
 QRC014, for 100m was drilled at the Titus South Prospect to test the anomalous gold values 
 in  RAB  hole  QRB655.  The  hole  intersected  hard,  unaltered  monzonite  porphyry  and 
 conglomerate. No values above 0.26 g/t Au were returned and no further work was undertaken 
 The main producing mines within the sedimentary basin within the Mulgabbie domain include 
 the  Yilgangi  Queen  which  produced  42  350.9  t  of  ore  for  1095.06  kg  Au  (25.9  g/t  Au) 
 between 1935 and 1982, Yilgangi which produced 1094.0 t of ore for 18.83 kg Au (17.2 g/t 
 Au) between 1903 and 1905 and Yilgangi King which produced 636.00 t of ore for 11.36 kg 
 Au (17.9 g/t Au) between 1924 and 1974 (Roberts.F.I. et al., 2000).  
 Total  production  for  the  Rainbow  Mine  deposits  as  at  31st  December  1987  is  given  as  1.2 
 tonnes of gold at an average grade of 25.0 g/t Au, with further reserves of 0.4 tonnes of gold at 
 17.0 g/t Au (GSWA Memoir 3).

7.text: A  total  of  17  drill  holes,  including  16  RAB  holes  and  1  RC  hole  drilled  by  Goldfields

text:
5.1 Data Compilation 
 During  the  2004  work  year  surface  geochemical  and  drilling  data  was  compiled  from 
 WAMEX Open file reports for the Yilgangi Project and adjacent areas.

 6.2 Geochemical Data Processing  
 Statistical  levelling  of  the  gold  from  the  surface  geochemical  database  which  includes  both  
 historical and recent sampling conducted by Jackson Gold for the Yilgangi Project area, has 
 been conducted by Jonno King during the 2005 - 2006 work year. The geochemical data set 
 comprises numerous discrete surveys or batches, the presence of differing backgrounds and 
 thresholds  commonly  causes  ‘edge  effects’  that  can  obscure  real  data  trends.  Levelling 
 involves a statistical manipulation of the data so as to minimize batch effects which include
